facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 65 and 66 of 1967 are appeals from the judgment and order dated September 16, 1966 of the Jammu and Kashmir High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 2 and 4 of 1966.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 65 and 66 of 1967. Appeals from the judgment and order dated September 16, 1966 of the Jammu and Kashmir High Court in Writ Petitions Nos. 2 and 4 of 1966.

facts.text: A Division Bench of the High Court of Jammu and Kashmir dismissed two writ petitions filed by the appellants seeking to quash the order refusing renewal of licences for 1966-67.

anchor.surface_text: These two appeals arise out of a companymon judgment of a Division Bench of the High Court of Jammu Kashmir dismissing the two petitions filed by the appellants for the issuance of a writ quashing the order passed by the Taxing and Excise Officer, Jammu, refusing to renew their licences for the year 1966-67 in respect of their liquor shops.

facts.text: Taxing and Excise Officer, Jammu refused to renew licences for liquor shops for the year 1966-67.

anchor.surface_text: quashing the order passed by the Taxing and Excise Officer, Jammu, refusing to renew their licences for the year 1966-67 in respect of their liquor shops.

facts.text: Appellant in Civil Appeal No. 65 is proprietor of Glory Restaurant situated in Moti Bazaar, Jammu.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 65 of 1967 relates to Glory Restaurant situated in Moti Bazaar, Jammu. The appellant in the said appeal, who is the proprietor of the said restaurant,

facts.text: Proprietor of Glory Restaurant carried on retail sale of country and foreign liquor for the last 7 years under annual licence renewed from year to year.

anchor.surface_text: after taking the requisite licence from the Government, had been carrying on for the last 7 years the business of retail sale of companyntry and foreign liquor in the said restaurant. The licence was an annual licence and it was being renewed from year to year.

facts.text: On December 11, 1965, Deputy Excise and Taxation Commissioner, Jammu issued notice to appellant in CA 65 ordering shifting of premises due to complaints from inhabitants.

anchor.surface_text: On December 11, 1965, the Deputy Excise and Taxation Commissioner, Jammu, issued a numberice to the appellant ordering the shifting of the premises of the said restaurant to some other locality on the ground that the inhabitants of the locality had companyplained against the location of the appellants bar and restaurant there.

facts.text: Licence for 1965-66 for Glory Restaurant expires on March 31, 1966.

anchor.surface_text: As the licence for 1965-66 would expire on March 31, 1966, the appellant applied for a fresh licence for 1966-67 and deposited the prescribed licence fee in the Government treasury.

facts.text: Appellant in CA 65 applied for fresh licence for 1966-67 and deposited prescribed fee.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant applied for a fresh licence for 1966-67 and deposited the prescribed licence fee in the Government treasury.

facts.text: Appellant in Civil Appeal No. 66 carried on business in liquor in Bliss Hotel and Bar situated in Parade Ground, Jammu under a licence.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant in Civil Appeal No. 66 of 1967 was carrying on business in liquor in his hotel, named Bliss Hotel and Bar, situated in Parade Ground, Jammu, under a licence issued by the Government of the said State.

facts.text: Appellant in CA 66 obtained licence for the first time in 1964.

anchor.surface_text: He obtained a licence for the first time in 1964.

facts.text: Appellant in CA 66 spent about Rs. 70,000 in furnishing the Hotel and Bar after obtaining licence.

anchor.surface_text: After obtaining the licence, it is alleged, he had spent about Rs. 70,000/- in furnishing the Hotel and Bar,

facts.text: Appellant in CA 66 could not do business during financial year 1964-65 for unavoidable reasons.

anchor.surface_text: but for unavoidable reasons he companyld number do business during the financial year 1964-65.

facts.text: On December 11, 1965, appellant in CA 66 received letter from Deputy Excise and Taxation Commissioner to shift premises due to complaints.

anchor.surface_text: For the year 1965-66 he made an application for the renewal of the licence and on December 11, 1965, he received a letter from the Deputy Excise and Taxation Commissioner, Jammu, desiring the appellant to shift the premises of his Hotel and Bar to some other suitable place after getting it approved by the Department on the ground that he had received companyplaints from the inhabitants of the locality against the location of the bar there.

facts.text: Licence of appellant in CA 66 was collected by 3rd respondent at instance of 2nd respondent.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the 2nd respondent, the Excise and Taxation Commissioner, Jammu, his licence, along with those of other licensees, was companylected by the 3rd respondent.

facts.text: Respondents pleaded that localities were most congested and frequented parts of the city and complaints were made against carrying on business there.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents opposed the petitions and pleaded, inter alia, that the localities wherein the petitioners were carrying on the business were the most companygested and frequented parts of the city and that, as companyplaints were made against their carrying on the business in the said localities, the respondents refused to renew their licences to carry on the said business in the said localities.

facts.text: Under the Excise Act, 1958, issuing of licence is at the discretion of the Excise Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: They also pleaded that under The Excise Act, 1958, hereinafter called the Act, the issuing of licence was at the discretion of the Excise Commissioner and he had, having regard to the companyplaints received, bona fide, in exercise of his discretion, refused to give licence to the appellants to carry on business in the said localities.

facts.text: High Court Division Bench consisting of Chief Justice and Justice Syed Murtaza Fazl Ali dismissed the writ petitions.

anchor.surface_text: In the High Court the Writ petitions, along with others, were decided by a Division Bench companysisting of Chief Justice and Justice Syed Murtaza Fazl Ali. They gave companycurrent but separate judgments.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that dealing in liquor is business and citizen has fundamental right subject to reasonable restrictions.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore, hold that dealing in liquor is business and a citizen has a right to do business in that companymodity but the State can make a law imposing reasonable restrictions on the said right, in public interests.

facts.text: Commissioner of Excise and Taxation made a bona fide enquiry and found locality not suitable.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges on a companysideration of the entire material placed before them, held that the Commissioner of Excise and Taxation made a bona fide enquiry and found that the locality was number suitable for carrying on business in liquor in view of the- various circumstances mentioned in the companynter-affidavit.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismisses the appeals with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result the appeals fall and are dismissed with companyts.

If s. 20 of the Act was construed as conferring an absolute discretion on the Commissioner of Excise and Taxation to issue or not to issue a licence to do business in liquor, it would be void on the ground that it infringed Art. 19 of the Constitution.

concepts.interpretation: Counsel contends that absolute discretion under S.20 would infringe Art.19(1)(g). Court clarifies citizen has fundamental right to business in liquor under Art.19(1)(g) subject to reasonable restrictions under Art.19(6).

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: mberhing to do with the companystruction of Art. 19  1   g  of the Constitution of India. The learned Judge was companysidering the scope of the polic

anchor.surface_text: Article 19 of the Constitution qua the right to do business reads thus All citizens shall have the right- g to practice any profession, or to carry on any occupation, trade or business. Nothing in sub-clause g of the said clause shall affect the operation of any existing law in so far as it imposes, or prevent the State from making any law imposing, in the interests of the general public, reasonable restrictions on the exercise of the right conferred by the said sub-clause

We, therefore, hold that dealing in liquor is business and a citizen has a right to do business in that commodity but the State can make a law imposing reasonable restrictions on the said right, in public interests.

concepts.interpretation: Dealing in liquor qualifies as business/trade under Art.19(1)(g); State may impose reasonable restrictions in public interest under Art.19(6).

holdings.text: dealing in liquor is business and a citizen has a right to do business in that commodity but the State can make a law imposing reasonable restrictions on the said right, in public interests.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of 'business' under Art.19(1)(g); distinguished precedents like Cooverjee B. Bharucha, State of Assam v. Kidwai which addressed reasonableness not existence of right.

holdings.text: the Commissioner of Excise and Taxation made a bona fide enquiry and found that the locality was not suitable for carrying on business in liquor... On the said finding it cannot be held that the order of the Commissioner was arbitrary or unreasonable.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Judges on a consideration of the entire material placed before them, held that the Commissioner of Excise and Taxation made a bona fide enquiry and found that the locality was not suitable for carrying on business in liquor in view of the- various circumstances mentioned in the counter-affidavit.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Upholds High Court finding of fact on material; bona fide enquiry suffices, no violation of natural justice or arbitrariness in discretionary refusal.

holdings.text: S. 22 controls s. 20 of the Act for the former deals with the cancellation of a licence and the latter with the issuance of a fresh licence they deal with two different subject-matters.

anchor.surface_text: We cannot agree with the learned counsel that S. 22 controls s. 20 of the Act for the former deals with the cancellation of a licence and the latter with the issuance of a fresh licence they deal with two different subject-matters.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory interpretation: distinct provisions for cancellation (S.22) vs issuance/renewal (S.20); no harmonious construction requiring same grounds.

holdings.text: the constitutional validity of S. 20 of the Act was not raised in the High Court. We cannot permit the appellant to raise that question for the first time before us.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural bar: new constitutional challenge not permitted if not raised below.

holdings.text: the order was mala fide. But this point was not pressed before the High Court and we cannot allow it to be raised for the first time before us.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural bar: allegation of mala fides not pressed below, cannot raise first time.

precedents.citation: Narain Swadeshi Weaving Mills v. The Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax 1

anchor.surface_text: Narain Swadeshi Weaving Mills v. The Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax 1 , the word business connote some real, substantial and systematic or organised course of activity or conduct with a set purpose. Even accepting this test, if the activity of a dealer, say, in ghee is business, then how does it cease to be business if it is in liquor ?

precedents.case_name: Narain Swadeshi Weaving Mills v. Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax
precedents.cited_proposition: definition of 'business' as connoting some real, substantial and systematic or organised course of activity or conduct with a set purpose
precedents.cited_holding: the word business connotes some real, substantial and systematic or organised course of activity or conduct with a set purpose

precedents.citation: B. Ibrahim v. Regional Transport Authority, Tanjore  2

anchor.surface_text: B. Ibrahim v. Regional Transport Authority, Tanjore  2  it was held that restriction placed upon the use of the bus- stand for the purpose of picking up or setting down passengers to or from outward journeys could not be considered to be an unreasonable restriction on the right to carry on.

precedents.case_name: B. Ibrahim v. Regional Transport Authority, Tanjore
precedents.cited_proposition: no fundamental right to carry on business wherever one chooses; subject to reasonable restrictions in public interest
precedents.cited_holding: There is no fundamental right in a citizen to carry on business wherever he chooses and his right must be subject to any reasonable restriction imposed by the executive authority in the interest of public convenience

precedents.citation: Cooverjee B. Bharucha v. The Excise Commissioner and the Chief Commissioner. Ajmer 3

anchor.surface_text: Cooverjee B. Bharucha v. The Excise Commissioner and the Chief Commissioner. Ajmer 3  lay down any such proposition. There the question was whether the Excise Regulation 1 of 1915 imposed a reasonable restriction within the meaning of Art. 19 6  of the Constitution on the right given under Art. 1 9  1    g  thereof to carry on the business in intoxicating liquors.

precedents.case_name: Cooverjee B. Bharucha v. Excise Commissioner and Chief Commissioner, Ajmer
precedents.cited_proposition: Excise Regulation imposing restrictions on liquor business is a reasonable restriction under Art. 19(6)

anchor.surface_text: Crowley v. Christensen 1 . In that extract the following passage is found - The police power of the State is fully competent to regulate the business to mitigate its evils or to suppress it entirely. There is no inherent right in a citizen to thus sell intoxicating liquors by retail it is not a privilege of a citizen of the State or of a citizen of the United States.

precedents.cited_proposition: no inherent right to sell intoxicating liquors; state can regulate or prohibit under police power
precedents.cited_holding: There is no inherent right in a citizen... to thus sell intoxicating liquors by retail... it may... be entirely prohibited

precedents.citation: The State of Assam v. A. N. Kidwai, Commissioner of Hills Division and Appeals, Shillong 2

anchor.surface_text: The State of Assam v. A. N. Kidwai, Commissioner of Hills Division and Appeals, Shillong 2  has no relevance to the present enquiry. The following- passage from the said judgment is relied upon A perusal of the Act and rules will make it clear that no person has any absolute right to sell liquor and that the purpose of the Act and the rules is to control and restrict the consumption of intoxicating liquors,

precedents.case_name: State of Assam v. A. N. Kidwai
precedents.cited_proposition: no absolute right to sell liquor; Act controls and restricts consumption for public health, morals, revenue
precedents.cited_holding: no person has any absolute right to sell liquor

precedents.cited_proposition: no inherent right to settlement of liquor shops (as noticed in Nagendra Nath)

precedents.citation: The State of Bombay v. R. M. D. Chamarbaugwala 4

anchor.surface_text: The State of Bombay v. R. M. D. Chamarbaugwala 4  upheld the validity of the Bombay Lotteries and Prize Competition Control and Tax Act, 1948  Bom. LIV of 1948 , as amended by the Bombay Lotteries and Prize Competition Control and Tax  Amendment  Act  Bombay Act XXX of 1952 . One of the questions raised was whether gambling was business or trade or commerce within the meaning of Art. 19  1   g  of the Constitution or Art. 301 thereof.

precedents.case_name: State of Bombay v. R. M. D. Chamarbaugwala
precedents.cited_proposition: gambling is not business, trade or commerce under Art. 19(1)(g)
